ol.li: From the AG menus, select Flow > Extract…
On the Signal tab, note that Extract signal nets is deselected (Figure 45).

body.p: When the Extract signal nets option is selected, full extraction is performed; the geometry found during the extraction is turned into pin geometry.
To use the pins created in the layout and duplicate them in the Abstract view, deselect Extract signal nets so that AG does not extract them.

p.i: Figure 46: Running step Extract, Signal tab, Extract signal nets option

image.alt: A screenshot of a computer Description automatically generated

ol.li: On the Power tab, Extract power nets is deselected (Figure 46).

body.p: For the power and ground rails for standard cells, the recommended approach is to create pins in the layout as duplicated in the Abstract view, instead of having AG extract them.

p.i: Figure 47: Running step Extract, Power tab, Extract power nets option

image.alt: A screenshot of a cell Description automatically generated

ol.li: On the Antenna tab, no options are enabled; this capability is under development for this technology (Figure 47).

body.p: “Antenna effect” is a common name for charge accumulation in isolated nodes of an integrated circuit during processing. It may damage transistors and degrade performance if discharged through the gate oxide. Adding antenna information into the layout abstract and LEF enables the P&R tools to calculate and mitigate the effect by jumping metal layers or adding an antenna diode.

p.i: Figure 48: Running step Extract, Antenna tab

image.alt: A screenshot of a computer Description automatically generated

ol.li: Click Run on the Running step Extract form (Figure 48).

p.i: Figure 49: AG UI, results from Extract step

image.alt: A screenshot of a computer Description automatically generated

body.p: For each standard cell in the library, a view named abstract.ext is created.
